body: This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.

I double this. I tried to debug this behaviour and found out that `LocalArtifactsRepository` is triggered because `ArtifactRepositoryRegistry.get_artifact_repository` parses artifact path from run information and treats it as local even though it is on a remote host. 
I'm using mlflow 1.6 and python 3.6 on both server and client machines.
Thank you for interacting with this issue! Removing the stale label!
Same problem here with python 3.6 and mlflow 1.6, I set a s3 bucket location as `--default-artifact-root` but all runs store artifacts locally...

Same here with Python 3.6.8 (Anaconda) and mlflow 1.6.0

```
$ MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI="http://mlflow-tracking-server:5000" python sklearn_logistic_regression/train.py
Score: 0.6666666666666666
Model saved in run 2c8164681cbe494a96c5ba336cc6006e

$ tree mlruns/0/2c8164681cbe494a96c5ba336cc6006e
mlruns/0/2c8164681cbe494a96c5ba336cc6006e
└── artifacts
    └── model
        ├── MLmodel
        ├── conda.yaml
        └── model.pkl

2 directories, 3 files
```

```
mlflow-tracking-server:~/mlflow> tree -FAC mlruns/0/2c8164681cbe494a96c5ba336cc6006e
mlruns/0/2c8164681cbe494a96c5ba336cc6006e
├── artifacts/
├── meta.yaml
├── metrics/
│   └── score
├── params/
└── tags/
    ├── mlflow.source.git.commit
    ├── mlflow.source.name
    ├── mlflow.source.type
    └── mlflow.user

4 directories, 6 files
```

Note that most of the tracking info (metrics, parameters, and tags) went to the remote server and only the model was written to local files and not sent to the server.
I got it working by specifying the artifact location in the experiment constructor.
@H4dr1en: Would you please share the code you used?

> I got it working by specifying the artifact location in the experiment constructor.

You basically just call `create_experiment` as defined in the [doc](https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/python_api/mlflow.tracking.html#mlflow.tracking.MlflowClient.create_experiment) and specify the `artifact_location` (S3 bucket, ftp server, etc) or with the [CLI](https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/rest-api.html#create-experiment). Then artifacts of the runs of that experiment are sent to that location.
Oh, I was curious what you used for `artifact_location` - e.g.: perhaps you might've used a `runs:/` URI?
Thanks! Ah yes, using S3 makes it easier to specify the location. I'm trying to use file storage on the tracking server, which might complicate things.
Then you would probably have to setup a simple static file server.
From the docs, I was under the impression that the tracking server would handle remote artifact storage, but I'm having issues with this as well.
Tracking server handle logging of metrics, not artifacts (at least not as of 1.6.0)

The language here suggests otherwise: 
https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/R-api.html#mlflow-download-artifacts
https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/R-api.html#mlflow-log-artifact

Edit: figured it out, didn't realize when you launch mlflow server you have to specify default-artifact-root, it doesn't act as an ftp server. Can you not specify default-artifact-root client side?

> I used `create_experiment("Experiment with remote artifacts", "s3://aws-bucket/")`

For me that worked as well (for NFS share). Do you have any idea how I can change the `artifact_uri` from existing experiments?

Hi folks, as pointed out by @mjlbach and others, MLflow does not currently support streaming / proxying artifacts through the MLflow server. We have an open ticket requesting this functionality and would love community contributions on the design front: https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/issues/629. 

For now, I'm going to resolve this ticket; it would be great to continue this discussion on https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/issues/629 and discuss options for implementing this behavior! Thank you!
